author: Andy Anderson
bottom_line: Prolonged warm weather without an overnight refreeze means wet snow avalanches and cornice failures will remain likely today.  Traveling on slopes not steep enough to avalanche and staying away from cornices can help reduce your exposure to these avalanche problems today.
hazard_discussion:
• Observers reported more wet loose avalanches and recent cornice failures yesterday all across the forecast area. 
  • Glide cracks have also started to form on steep slopes in rocky areas. Like cornices, glide crack failures are notoriously difficult to predict, and staying away from slopes with glide cracks represents the best course of action.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion:
Little to no refreeze likely occurred last night due to increased cloud cover and above-freezing temperatures. Expect to find barely supportable or already wet snow on all aspects this morning. Wet snow avalanches will remain likely today on any slope steep enough for snow to slide downhill. Some of these could be large enough to cause problems for backcountry travelers, especially on long slopes where a wet loose avalanche will entrain more snow as it moves. 

Signs that the snowpack has become wet enough for wet snow avalanches include pinwheels, rollerballs, sinking into ankle-deep wet snow when you step off your sled or skis, and wet loose avalanches. An early start may not help avoid unstable wet snow today due to the lack of an overnight refreeze, but recreating on slopes less steep than 35 ° without steeper slopes above can reduce the risk of encountering wet snow avalanches.

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Wet Loose
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Wet Loose avalanches are the release of wet unconsolidated snow or slush. These avalanches typically occur within layers of wet snow near the surface of the snowpack, but they may quickly gouge into lower snowpack layers. Like Loose Dry Avalanches, they start at a point and entrain snow as they move downhill, forming a fan-shaped avalanche. Other names for loose-wet avalanches include point-release avalanches or sluffs. Loose Wet avalanches can trigger slab avalanches that break into deeper snow layers.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion:
The prolonged warm weather and lack of a refreeze means that the cornices along many ridgelines remain weak. Cornice failures will likely continue today. Large to massive blocks falling off these overhanging waves of snow could cause problems on their own or trigger wet snow avalanches on the slopes below.

Predicting exactly when a cornice will fail is nearly impossible. Cornice failures almost always surprise the people who trigger them by failing farther away from the edge than expected, failing much larger than expected, and failing at an unexpected time. Stay well away from cornices by putting exposed rocks or trees between you and the cornice. Consider avoiding travel on slopes below cornices.

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Cornice Fall
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Cornice Fall is the release of an overhanging mass of snow that forms as the wind moves snow over a sharp terrain feature, such as a ridge, and deposits snow on the downwind (leeward) side. Cornices range in size from small wind drifts of soft snow to large overhangs of hard snow that are 30 feet (10 meters) or taller. They can break off the terrain suddenly and pull back onto the ridge top and catch people by surprise even on the flat ground above the slope. Even small cornices can have enough mass to be destructive and deadly. Cornice Fall can entrain loose surface snow or trigger slab avalanches.
